For Release Sunday, Dec. 24, and Thereafter
Bush's Once-Vague Phrase Gaining Meaning
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Withstanding parodies and put-downs, President Bush's Thousand Points of Light have flickered from a cryptic campaign slogan into a federal program to foster the volunteer spirit in America. Not bad, given that Bush himself once confessed he wasn't really certain what the phrase meant, much as he liked the lilt of the words. So there are a thousand points of light _ at least there are supposed to be _ glittering from the national Christmas tree on the Ellipse behind the White House. And the president's point-of-light lieutenant has been issuing citations recognizing ``daily points of light,'' individuals and organizations engaged in community service to help solve social problems. ``We will single out the few because they represent the many,'' Bush said. ``We hope that by highlighting their achievements, and the ways they've found to serve, we can inspire others to serve.'' And yes, there is a point-of-light man at the White House. C. Gregg Petersmeyer, a Denver businessman who worked in the Bush campaign, is director of the Office of National Service; his assignment is to mobilize the campaign for volunteer efforts. The administration will be seeking congressional backing for a Points of Light Initiative Foundation, to manage a nationwide drive to enlist people in community service. The government already has programs to organize volunteer efforts, among them VISTA, ACTION, and the Older American Volunteer program. Congress approved an extension of those programs through 1993 just before adjourning this year. Bush is expected to ask Congress to provide $25 million in each of the next four years to help finance the foundation, with matching amounts to be sought from private donors. The goal, according to Petersmeyer, will be to encourage every citizen to get involved in at least one community service activity. Every business also will be asked to join the effort to mobilize volunteers to cope with hunger, homelessness, drug abuse, juvenile crime and other social ills. The president appointed an advisory committee headed by retiring Gov. Thomas Kean of New Jersey to plan the foundation and work on the legislation to create it. At its first meeting, Petersmeyer told the five members that power is flowing from the government to the people with the effort to promote volunteerism. The panel is to meet again next month to deliver its final report to Bush. So far, as least, the points of light do not seem to have multiplied, despite the president's emphasis on volunteer efforts. A Gallup poll conducted six weeks ago showed no measurable increase in charitable or social service activities during the past two years. According to that survey, 41 percent of Americans say they are involved in volunteer work. Two years ago it was 39 percent. The numbers go up sharply when the question is of charitable contributions rather than volunteer work. More than 70 percent said they had made donations to charity in the past year. The phrase that has become the Bush theme on voluntary efforts dates from his speech to the Republican National Convention in 1988. Bush ticked off names of 10 organizations, from the Grange to the Business and Professional Women of America, and called them all elements in ``a brilliant diversity spread like stars, like a thousand points of light in a broad and peaceful sky.'' ``I will keep America moving forward, always forward, for a better America, for an endless enduring dream and a thousand points of light,'' he said as he concluded. Speechwriter Peggy Noonan is credited with writing the line. Bush grabbed it and ran, although he tripped now and then as he repeated the refrain during the campaign. He spoke of ``a thousand points of life,'' and of ``a thousand shining hills.'' And at first, he acknowledged that he couldn't define exactly what it meant. But eventually, practice made perfect. When Gov. Michael Dukakis complained in a campaign debate that ``I don't know what that means,'' Bush said that was typical of big-spending liberals who think the government should do everything. He said he was talking about the enormous number of people and organizations willing to help others. It was part of his inaugural address, ``a thousand points of light ... all the community organizations that are spread like stars throughout the nation, doing good.'' Now it is part of his administration.
Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.
